hackathon-description-text: This November 13-15, HackPrinceton will bring together over 600 of the nation's most promising developers and designers to create incredible software and hardware projects. Meet fellow hackers, learn new technologies, and hone your skills alongside seasoned mentors. Whether you’re making your first mobile app or are ready to jump onboard the most developed hardware track in the country, join us for 36 glorious hours of learning.

hackathon-judges.judge-role: VP of Network Operations at PIA
Director of Android Engineering at Hooks Technologies Inc. and Co-founder at Androidsx
Founder & CEO at Astro, makers of TwistHome

hackathon-rules:
All participants must abide by the 
.
All projects must be created entirely within the 36-hour span beginning Friday 9pm and Sunday 9am. Projects are free (and encouraged) to make use of any existing, publicly-available code or hardware not built for the express purpose of the hackathon. For example, a project may make use of open-source community libraries, but cannot make use of code written by team members specifically for the hackathon. Organizers reserve the right to determine the eligibility of a project.
hackathon-requirements:
We welcome both hardware and software hacks! We're looking forward to what you produce, but please keep the following in mind.
Submissions should be reasonably complete to be considered for any prizes and reimbursements. They must be submitted to Devpost
hackathon-description-header: This November 13-15th, some of the nation's best and brightest hackers will converge at Princeton University to create unforgettable software and hardware projects.

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: Amazon Echo + Dell tablets + interview for a spot in an Entrepreneurs Roundtable Accelerator program (chance for $40,000 in seed funding) + JetBrains license for product of choice + one year of Squarespace
$250 + Jawbone MINI JAMBOX + interview for a spot in an Entrepreneurs Roundtable Accelerator program (chance for $40,000 in seed funding) + one year of Squarespace
3-month subscription to Birchbox + interview for a spot in an Entrepreneurs Roundtable Accelerator program (chance for $40,000 in seed funding) + one year of Squarespace
Sphero BB-8 App-Enabled Droid from the upcoming Star Wars film, The Force Awakens (up to 4)
Trip for 4 to the Global Hackathon Finals in Menlo Park, CA in Fall of 2016
Domain.com swag bag, containing a SparkFun RedBoard. Sponsored by Major League Hacking.
Best use of AWS gets a 1TB hard drive. Sponsored by Major League Hacking.

Private Internet Access would like to award three prizes for hacks that promote and improve the security and privacy of Internet users. Hacks will be judged on 3 criteria: uniqueness of the idea, ease of use, implementation.
hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Best Privacy and Security Hacks - First Place

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: Private Internet Access would like to award three prizes for hacks that promote and improve the security and privacy of Internet users. Hacks will be judged on 3 criteria: uniqueness of the idea, ease of use, implementation. 2nd Place: $1,000
hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Best Privacy and Security Hacks - Second Place

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: Private Internet Access would like to award three prizes for hacks that promote and improve the security and privacy of Internet users. Hacks will be judged on 3 criteria: uniqueness of the idea, ease of use, implementation. 3rd Place: $500
hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Best Privacy and Security Hacks - Third Place

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: Winner gets a tablet. Sponsored by Linode, LLC.

hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Most Interesting Use of the Twitter API

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: 2 BTC, as well as in-person interviews for a summer internship position in NYC. Sponsored by Blockchain.
Winners receive an interview for the next round of the KPCB Engineering Fellows Program Application cycle.
Winning team gets $2000. Sponsored by WalmartLabs.

hackathon-judging-criteria.judging-criterion: How original is the idea? Is it simply a repackaging of a previous project (i.e. Floppy Bird) or is it something that has never been done before? Projects can also blend two concepts together in a refreshing new way (i.e. chocolate-covered bacon).
Does it feel like a quickly hacked-together project, or something that is well thought out? Is the user experience and interface smooth and well-designed?
Can this hack be used in real life to better somebody's life? Is it enough to justify people wanting to use it?
Is the project zany, interesting or just plain amusing? Will it bring a smile to the face of those who see it, whether they are adults, teenagers or little kids?
Does the project take on technical challenges? What parts of the project did your team invent, and how did you build upon existing tools and technologies?
